repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
It's a common misconception about vimscript that the User autocmd is special, and many people (previously myself included) don't realize that the event name given to the autocommand is just a regular pattern.

To eliminate this misconception, and to make it clear how to make a User autocommand, an example is added to illustrate that the event name is  just a regular pattern.

I am very much open to bikeshedding over phrasing in general and what the example looks like, it was adapted from the `User` event example in the vimscript documentation.

comment_data.body: note: this file is autogenerated and this change has to be done to the docstring of `nvim_create_autocmd` in `src/nvim/api/autocmd.c`. Then use `make doc` to synchronize this file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3363,6 +3363,13 @@ nvim_create_autocmd({event}, {*opts})                  *nvim_create_autocmd()*
         })
 <
 
+    Example using a User command: >lua

comment_data.body: Thanks for the heads up, fixed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3363,6 +3363,13 @@ nvim_create_autocmd({event}, {*opts})                  *nvim_create_autocmd()*
         })
 <
 
+    Example using a User command: >lua

comment_data.body:
This may add slightly more confusion because it's not a MyPlugin event, it's a User event.

```suggestion
          command = "echomsg 'got User event'",
```

This and https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24793 are special-cases because of usability issues with the User event. Or the documentation for the User event is misleading, maybe that should be fixed instead...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3363,6 +3363,13 @@ nvim_create_autocmd({event}, {*opts})                  *nvim_create_autocmd()*
         })
 <
 
+    Example using a User autocommand: >lua
+        vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("User", {
+          pattern = "MyPlugin",
+          command = "echo 'got MyPlugin event'",

comment_data.body:
Maybe there could be both in the string for the sake of explicitness? i.e. `"echomsg 'got MyPlugin user event"`

While updating the User event docs would probably help, I think that because most autocommands have a file name glob as their pattern, there's an impulse to assume that all patterns are file name globs, and that something special is going on when encountering the User event which does something else.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3363,6 +3363,13 @@ nvim_create_autocmd({event}, {*opts})                  *nvim_create_autocmd()*
         })
 <
 
+    Example using a User autocommand: >lua
+        vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("User", {
+          pattern = "MyPlugin",
+          command = "echo 'got MyPlugin event'",

comment_data.body:
Yes, but that's an unfounded assumption (`User` is not the only such event; the same applies, e.g., to `FileType`). There's two things at play here:
1. technical documentation, which needs to be clear and correct but not "robust against prior miscomprehension";
2. user manual, which _should_ guard against such miscomprehension.

It is a difficulty that (Neo)Vim's documentation is sprawling and contains both. I agree with @justinmk that the best place for a better explanation is the canonical place, which is `:h User`. For example, we can add a (single) sentence such as (addition bold):


> Not executed automatically.  Use |:doautocmd| to trigger this, typically for "custom events" in a plugin.  **Specify a custom pattern to distinguish different events or plugins.** Example:  

Then any other location in the docs can just link to that, if needed. Also, I'd like to point out that we already have this exact example in `:h lua-guide-autocommand-create`, which is the closest we currently have to a "Neovim user manual" as opposed to API reference.

>  "echomsg 'got MyPlugin user event"

This is not great, as it again conflates the intention ("event triggered by MyPlugin") from the implementation ("`User` event with `MyPlugin` pattern").
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3363,6 +3363,13 @@ nvim_create_autocmd({event}, {*opts})                  *nvim_create_autocmd()*
         })
 <
 
+    Example using a User autocommand: >lua
+        vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("User", {
+          pattern = "MyPlugin",
+          command = "echo 'got MyPlugin event'",

comment_regular_data.body: This is also present in `:h lua-guide-autocommand-create`
